طيب بعد ما عدينا مستوى توفير كهرباء بديلة عن الشبكة القومية
وصلنا للمستوى اللي بعده، توفير انترنت بديلة :)

Knowing that the world doesn't actually needs a new language .. but I would really like to share with you my new (uncompleted) dynamic language .. with an early draft of its specifications

http://specs.quantitysystem.org/en/latest/RuntimeTypes.html

the calculator can be tested on http://quantitysystem.org

and the source code is available in http://quantitysystem.codeplex.com until I move it into github.

emm the language is concerned about units conversion and keeping consistency of quantities regardless of used units.

for example you can get the length with any unit you want .. aah and you can try currency conversion as well by writing  0<EGP>+1000<USD> for example :D
posts.caption: specs.quantitysystem.org
posts.description: All the runtime types are inherited from the QsValue reference type. These types has gone through a careful architecture to describe the sematics of the language elements.

posts.message:
Not your typical post, but I'm sure at least some of you will appreciate this. The paper that sparked all research in brain-machine interfaces:

"Real-time control of a robot arm using simultaneously recorded neurons in the motor cortex " 

Chapin et al.,

TL;DR: This is the first published effort to record neuronal activity and use it to electronically drive actuators in a robot-arm. The implications at the time were that this could lead to prostheses that are directly controlled by the brain, and "feel natural". There's still *a lot* to be done in that area, but things like feedback and bi-directional interfaces have already been demonstrated. Meaning, there are now research prosthetic arms with which humans can "feel" things like touch and finger/palm formation. Things which we take for-granted, but are actually critical.

https://courses.cs.washington.edu/courses/cse490i/07wi/papers/paper011.pdf

EDIT: In case you're *really* interested, this review article, though somewhat dated (2006), does a decent job at giving an overview of BMIs:

https://cs.rochester.edu/~kautz/Courses/290Bspring2008/NeuroRobots/TiNS_2006.pdf
posts.caption: courses.cs.washington.edu

posts.message: Curious about how the I/O 2015 Experiment was built? Check out this case study from the agency Instrument, who in partnership with the Chrome Developer Relations team, used WebGL and Web Audio to create an engaging, delightful Chrome Experiment.  #io15  ﻿
posts.caption: instrument.com
posts.description: My name is Thomas Reynolds. Five years ago, I stumbled across the Google I/O 2011 Experiment, which was an incredibly fun HTML5 Canvas countdown by some little agency in Portland, Oregon. I reached out to Instrument and told them that things like that are exactly what I want to be building every sin…
